member.summary: A generic version of the FocusEvent class. The type parameter is a type of CurrentTarget.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.FocusEvent`1.CurrentTarget
member.summary: Identifies the current target for the event, as the event traverses the DOM. It always refers to the element the event handler has been attached to as opposed to event.target which identifies the element on which the event occurred. On Internet Explorer 6 through 8, the event model is different. Event listeners are attached with the non-standard element.attachEvent method. In this model, there is no equivalent to event.currentTarget and this is the global object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.FocusEvent`1.Target
member.summary: This property of event objects is the object the event was dispatched on. It is different than event.currentTarget when the event handler is called in bubbling or capturing phase of the event. On IE6-8, the event model is different. Event listeners are attached with the non-standard element.attachEvent method. In this model, the event object is not passed as an argument to the event handler function but is the window.event object. This object has an srcElement property which has the same semantics than event.target.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.HashChangeEvent.NewURL
member.summary: The new URL to which the window is navigating.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.HashChangeEvent.OldURL
member.summary: The previous URL from which the window was navigated.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.HashChangeEvent`1
member.summary: A generic version of the HashChangeEvent class. The type parameter is a type of CurrentTarget.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.HashChangeEvent`1.CurrentTarget
member.summary: Identifies the current target for the event, as the event traverses the DOM. It always refers to the element the event handler has been attached to as opposed to event.target which identifies the element on which the event occurred. On Internet Explorer 6 through 8, the event model is different. Event listeners are attached with the non-standard element.attachEvent method. In this model, there is no equivalent to event.currentTarget and this is the global object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.HashChangeEvent`1.Target
member.summary: This property of event objects is the object the event was dispatched on. It is different than event.currentTarget when the event handler is called in bubbling or capturing phase of the event. On IE6-8, the event model is different. Event listeners are attached with the non-standard element.attachEvent method. In this model, the event object is not passed as an argument to the event handler function but is the window.event object. This object has an srcElement property which has the same semantics than event.target.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.IEventListener.HandleEvent(Bridge.Html5.Event)
member.summary: This method is called whenever an event occurs of the type for which the EventListener interface was registered.
member.param: The DOM Event to register.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.AltKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the ALT key was pressed when the event fired.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.CharCode
member.summary: The Unicode reference number of the key; this attribute is used only by the 'keypress' event. For keys whose char attribute contains multiple characters, this is the Unicode value of the first character in that attribute. In Firefox 26 this returns codes for printable characters.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.CtrlKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the CTRL key was pressed when the event fired.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.IsComposing
member.summary: true if the event is fired between after compositionstart and before compositionend.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.KeyCode
member.summary:
Returns the Unicode value of a non-character key in a keypress event or any key in any other type of keyboard event.
In a keypress event, the Unicode value of the key pressed is stored in either the keyCode or charCode property, never both. If the key pressed generates a character (e.g. 'a'), charCode is set to the code of that character, respecting the letter case. (i.e. charCode takes into account whether the shift key is held down). Otherwise, the code of the pressed key is stored in keyCode.
keyCode is always set in the keydown and keyup events. In these cases, charCode is never set.
To get the code of the key regardless of whether it was stored in keyCode or charCode, query the which property.
Characters entered through an IME do not register through keyCode or charCode.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.Key
member.summary: The key value of the key represented by the event. If the value has a printed representation, this attribute's value is the same as the char attribute. Otherwise, it's one of the key value strings specified in {{anch("Key values")}}. If the key can't be identified, this is the string "Unidentified". See key names for the detail. In Firefox 26 this has a valid string for non-printable characters, and some printable characters (e.g. Tab, Enter). For regular characters it returns only "MozPrintableKey". charCode works and returns the character code.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.Locale
member.summary: A locale string indicating the locale the keyboard is configured for. This may be the empty string if the browser or device doesn't know the keyboard's locale.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.Location
member.summary: The location of the key on the keyboard or other input device

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.MetaKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the "meta" key was pressed when the event fired. Note: On the Macintosh, this is the Command key. On Microsoft Windows, this is the Windows key.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.ShiftKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the SHIFT key was pressed when the event fired.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.Which
member.summary: Returns the numeric keyCode of the key pressed, or the character code (charCode) for an alphanumeric key pressed.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.Repeat
member.summary: true if the key is being held down such that it is automatically repeating.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.GetModifierState(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the current state of the specified modifier key.
member.param: A string identifying the modifier key whose value you wish to determine. This may be an implementation-defined value or one of: "Alt", "AltGraph", "CapsLock", "Control", "Fn", "Meta", "NumLock", "ScrollLock", "Shift", "SymbolLock", or "OS". Note that IE9 uses "Scroll" for "ScrollLock" and "Win" for "OS". If you use these older draft's name, Gecko's getModifierState() always returns false.
member.returns: true if the specified modifier key is engaged; otherwise false.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent.InitKeyEvent(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,Bridge.Html5.WindowInstance,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: The initKeyEvent method is used to initialize the value of an event created using document.createEvent("KeyboardEvent")
member.param: The type of event.
A boolean indicating whether the event should bubble up through the event chain or not (see bubbles).
A boolean indicating whether the event can be canceled.
Specifies UIEvent.view. This value may be null.
bool True if the Virtual Key to be generated is a combination of the Ctrl key and other keys
bool True if the Virtual Key to be generated is a combination of the Alt key and other keys
bool True if the Virtual Key to be generated is a combination of the Shift key and other keys
bool True if the Virtual Key to be generated is a combination of the Meta key and other keys
unsigned long the virtual key code value of the key which was depressed, otherwise zero
unsigned long the Unicode character associated with the depressed key otherwise zero

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEventInit.KeyCode
member.summary:
Returns the Unicode value of a non-character key in a keypress event or any key in any other type of keyboard event.
In a keypress event, the Unicode value of the key pressed is stored in either the keyCode or charCode property, never both. If the key pressed generates a character (e.g. 'a'), charCode is set to the code of that character, respecting the letter case. (i.e. charCode takes into account whether the shift key is held down). Otherwise, the code of the pressed key is stored in keyCode.
keyCode is always set in the keydown and keyup events. In these cases, charCode is never set.
To get the code of the key regardless of whether it was stored in keyCode or charCode, query the which property.
Characters entered through an IME do not register through keyCode or charCode.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEventInit.CharCode
member.summary: The Unicode reference number of the key; this attribute is used only by the 'keypress' event. For keys whose char attribute contains multiple characters, this is the Unicode value of the first character in that attribute. In Firefox 26 this returns codes for printable characters.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.KeyLocation
member.summary: These constants describe the location on the keyboard of key events.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyLocation.Standard
member.summary: The key must not be distinguished between the left and right versions of the key, and was not pressed on the numeric keypad or a key that is considered to be part of the keypad.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyLocation.Left
member.summary: The key was the left-hand version of the key; for example, this is the value of the location attribute when the left-hand Control key is pressed on a standard 101 key US keyboard. This value is only used for keys that have more that one possible location on the keyboard.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyLocation.Right
member.summary: The key was the right-hand version of the key; for example, this is the value of the location attribute when the right-hand Control key is pressed on a standard 101 key US keyboard. This value is only used for keys that have more that one possible location on the keyboard.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyLocation.Numpad
member.summary: The key was on the numeric keypad, or has a virtual key code that corresponds to the numeric keypad.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyLocation.Mobile
member.summary: The key was on a mobile device; this can be on either a physical keypad or a virtual keyboard.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyLocation.Joystick
member.summary: The key was a button on a game controller or a joystick on a mobile device.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent`1
member.summary: A generic version of the KeyboardEvent class. The type parameter is a type of CurrentTarget.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent`1.CurrentTarget
member.summary: Identifies the current target for the event, as the event traverses the DOM. It always refers to the element the event handler has been attached to as opposed to event.target which identifies the element on which the event occurred. On Internet Explorer 6 through 8, the event model is different. Event listeners are attached with the non-standard element.attachEvent method. In this model, there is no equivalent to event.currentTarget and this is the global object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.KeyboardEvent`1.Target
member.summary: This property of event objects is the object the event was dispatched on. It is different than event.currentTarget when the event handler is called in bubbling or capturing phase of the event. On IE6-8, the event model is different. Event listeners are attached with the non-standard element.attachEvent method. In this model, the event object is not passed as an argument to the event handler function but is the window.event object. This object has an srcElement property which has the same semantics than event.target.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.AltKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the ALT key was pressed when the event fired.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.Button
member.summary:
Indicates which mouse button caused the event. This property returns an integer value indicating the button that changed state.
0 for standard "click"; this is usually the left button for a right-handed mouse and right button for a left-handed mouse. 1 for middle button; this is usually a click on the scroll wheel's button. 2 for right button; this is usually a right-click on a right-handed mouse and left-click on a left-handed mouse.
Note: This convention is not followed in Internet Explorer prior to version 9: See QuirksMode for details (http://www.quirksmode.org/js/events_properties.html#button).
Notes
Because mouse clicks are frequently intercepted by the user interface, it may be difficult to detect buttons other than those for a standard mouse click (usually the left button) in some circumstances.
Users may change the configuration of buttons on their pointing device so that if an event's button property is zero, it may not have been caused by the button that is physically leftâmost on the pointing device; however, it should behave as if the left button was clicked in the standard button layout.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.Buttons
member.summary:
The buttons being pressed when the mouse event was fired Each button that can be pressed is representd by a given number (see below). If more than one button is pressed, the value of the buttons is combined to produce a new number. For example, if the right button (2) and the wheel button (4) are pressed, the value is equal to 2|4, which is 6. A number representing one or more buttons. For more than one button pressed, the values are combined.
1 : Left button 2 : Right button 4 : Wheel button 8 : 4th button (typically the "Browser Back" button) 16 : 5th button (typically the "Browser Forward" button)

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.ClientX
member.summary: Returns the horizontal coordinate within the application's client area at which the event occurred (as opposed to the coordinates within the page). For example, clicking in the top-left corner of the client area will always result in a mouse event with a clientX value of 0, regardless of whether the page is scrolled horizontally.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.ClientY
member.summary: Returns the vertical coordinate within the application's client area at which the event occurred (as opposed to the coordinates within the page). For example, clicking in the top-left corner of the client area will always result in a mouse event with a clientY value of 0, regardless of whether the page is scrolled vertically.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.CtrlKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the CTRL key was pressed when the event fired.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.Detail
member.summary: Returns additional numerical information about the event, depending on the type of event. For mouse events, such as click, dblclick, mousedown, or mouseup, the detail property indicates how many times the mouse has been clicked in the same location for this event. For a dblclick event the value of detail is always 2.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.MetaKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the "meta" key was pressed when the event fired. Note: On the Macintosh, this is the Command key. On Microsoft Windows, this is the Windows key.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.ScreenX
member.summary: Returns the horizontal coordinate of the event within the screen as a whole.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.ScreenY
member.summary: Returns the vertical coordinate of the event within the screen as a whole.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.ShiftKey
member.summary: Indicates whether the SHIFT key was pressed when the event fired.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.RelatedTarget
member.summary: The secondary target for the event, if there is one.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.MovementX
member.summary: The X coordinate of the mouse pointer relative to the position of the last mousemove event.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.MovementY
member.summary: The Y coordinate of the mouse pointer relative to the position of the last mousemove event.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.MouseEvent.GetModifierState(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the current state of the specified modifier key.
member.param: A string identifying the modifier key whose value you wish to determine. This may be an implementation-defined value or one of: "Alt", "AltGraph", "CapsLock", "Control", "Fn", "Meta", "NumLock", "ScrollLock", "Shift", "SymbolLock", or "OS". Note that IE9 uses "Scroll" for "ScrollLock" and "Win" for "OS". If you use these older draft's name, Gecko's getModifierState() always returns false.
member.returns: true if the specified modifier key is engaged; otherwise false.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.ProgressEvent
member.summary: The ProgressEvent interface represents events measuring progress of an underlying process, like an HTTP request (for an XMLHttpRequest, or the loading of the underlying resource of an ,

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ProgressEvent.LengthComputable
member.summary: Is a Boolean flag indicating if the total work to be done, and the amount of work already done, by the underlying process is calculable. In other words, it tells if the progress is measurable or not.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ProgressEvent.Loaded
member.summary: Is an unsigned long long representing the amount of work already performed by the underlying process. The ratio of work done can be calculated with the property and ProgressEvent.total. When downloading a resource using HTTP, this only represent the part of the content itself, not headers and other overhead.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ProgressEvent.Total
member.summary: Is an unsigned long long representing the total amount of work that the underlying process is in the progress of performing. When downloading a resource using HTTP, this only represent the content itself, not headers and other overhead.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.UIEvent.EventPhase
member.summary: Indicates which phase of the event flow is currently being evaluated. Returns an integer value represented by 4 constants: Event.NONE = 0 Event.CAPTURING_PHASE = 1 Event.AT_TARGET = 2 Event.BUBBLING_PHASE = 3

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.UIEvent.LayerX
member.summary: Returns the horizontal coordinate of the event relative to the current layer. LayerX takes scrolling of the page into account, and returns a value relative to the whole of the document, unless the event occurs inside a positioned element, where the returned value is relative to the top left of the positioned element.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.UIEvent.LayerY

LayerY takes scrolling of the page into account, and returns a value relative to the whole of the document, unless the event occurs inside a positioned element, where the returned value is relative to the top left of the positioned element.

member.summary: The method registers the specified listener on the EventTarget it's called on. The event target may be an Element in a document, the Document itself, a Window, or any other object that supports events.
member.param: A string representing the event type to listen for.

member.summary: Dispatches the specified event to the current element. To create an event object use the createEvent method in Firefox, Opera, Google Chrome, Safari and Internet Explorer from version 9. After the new event is created, initialize it first (for details, see the page for the createEvent method). When the event is initialized, it is ready for dispatching.
member.param: Required. Reference to an event object to be dispatched.
member.returns: Boolean that indicates whether the default action of the event was not canceled.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Blob
member.summary: A Blob object represents a file-like object of immutable, raw data. Blobs represent data that isn't necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. The File interface is based on Blob, inheriting blob functionality and expanding it to support files on the user's system. An easy way to construct a Blob is by invoking the Blob constuctor. Another way is to use the slice() method to create a blob that contains a subset of another blob's data.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Blob.#ctor(Bridge.Html5.BlobDataObject[])
member.param: An Array of data objects to put into the new Blob object. This can be any number of ArrayBuffer, ArrayBufferView (typed array), Blob, or strings, in any order.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Blob.#ctor(Bridge.Html5.BlobDataObject[],Bridge.Html5.BlobPropertyBag)
member.param: An Array of data objects to put into the new Blob object. This can be any number of ArrayBuffer, ArrayBufferView (typed array), Blob, or strings, in any order.
A BlobPropertyBag object that provides the properties for the new Blob object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Blob.Size
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the data contained in the Blob object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Blob.Type
member.summary: A string indicating the MIME type of the data contained in the Blob. If the type is unknown, this string is empty.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Blob.Slice
member.summary: Returns a new Blob object containing the data in the specified range of bytes of the source Blob.
member.returns: A new Blob object containing the specified data from the source Blob.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Blob.Slice(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a new Blob object containing the data in the specified range of bytes of the source Blob.
member.param: An index into the Blob indicating the first byte to copy into the new Blob. If you specify a negative value, it's treated as an offset from the end of the string toward the beginning. For example, -10 would be the 10th from last byte in the Blob. The default value is 0. If you specify a value for start that is larger than the size of the source Blob, the returned Blob has size 0 and contains no data.
member.returns: A new Blob object containing the specified data from the source Blob.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Blob.Slice(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a new Blob object containing the data in the specified range of bytes of the source Blob.
member.param: An index into the Blob indicating the first byte to copy into the new Blob. If you specify a negative value, it's treated as an offset from the end of the string toward the beginning. For example, -10 would be the 10th from last byte in the Blob. The default value is 0. If you specify a value for start that is larger than the size of the source Blob, the returned Blob has size 0 and contains no data.

An index into the Blob indicating the last byte to copy into the new Blob. If you specify a negative value, it's treated as an offset from the end of the string toward the beginning. For example, -10 would be the 10th from last byte in the Blob. The default value is size.
member.returns: A new Blob object containing the specified data from the source Blob.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Blob.Slice(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Returns a new Blob object containing the data in the specified range of bytes of the source Blob.
member.param: An index into the Blob indicating the first byte to copy into the new Blob. If you specify a negative value, it's treated as an offset from the end of the string toward the beginning. For example, -10 would be the 10th from last byte in the Blob. The default value is 0. If you specify a value for start that is larger than the size of the source Blob, the returned Blob has size 0 and contains no data.

An index into the Blob indicating the last byte to copy into the new Blob. If you specify a negative value, it's treated as an offset from the end of the string toward the beginning. For example, -10 would be the 10th from last byte in the Blob. The default value is size.
The content type to assign to the new Blob; this will be the value of its type property. The default value is an empty string.
member.returns: A new Blob object containing the specified data from the source Blob.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.BlobPropertyBag
member.summary: A BlobPropertyBag object that provides the properties for the new Blob object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.BlobPropertyBag.Type
member.summary: A string representing the MIME type of the Blob object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.BlobPropertyBag.Endings
member.summary: Specifies how strings containing \n are to be written out. This can be "transparent" (endings unchanged) or "native" (endings changed to match host OS filesystem convention). The default value is "transparent". It corresponds to the endings parameter of the deprecated BlobBuilder.append().

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Endings
member.summary: Specifies how strings containing \n are to be written out.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Endings.Transparent
member.summary: Endings unchanged

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Endings.Native
member.summary: Endings changed to match host OS filesystem convention

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.File
member.summary: The File interface provides information about -- and access to the contents of -- files. These are generally retrieved from a FileList object returned as a result of a user selecting files using the <input> element, from a drag and drop operation's DataTransfer object, or from the mozGetAsFile() API on an HTMLCanvasElement. The file reference can be saved when the form is submitted while the user is offline, so that the data can be retrieved and uploaded when the Internet connection is restored.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.File.Name
member.summary: The name of the file referenced by the File object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.File.LastModifiedDate
member.summary: The last modified Date of the file referenced by the File object.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.FileList
member.summary: An object of this type is returned by the files property of the HTML input element; this lets you access the list of files selected with the <input type="file"> element. It's also used for a list of files dropped into web content when using the drag and drop API; see the DataTransfer object for details on this usage.

member.name: P:Bridge.Html5.FileList.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a File object representing the file at the specified index in the file list.
member.param: The zero-based index of the file to retrieve from the list.
member.returns: The File representing the requested file.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.FileList.GetItem(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a File object representing the file at the specified index in the file list.
member.param: The zero-based index of the file to retrieve from the list.
member.returns: The File representing the requested file.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.FileList.Length
member.summary: A read-only value indicating the number of files in the list.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.FormControlsCollection
member.summary: The HTMLFormControlsCollection interface represents a collection of HTML form control elements. It provides one additional method besides the properties and methods inherited from HTMLCollection. This interface is used by the HTMLFormElement interface's elements property, and the HTMLFieldSetElement interface's elements property.

member.name: P:Bridge.Html5.FormControlsCollection.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the node or list of nodes in the collection whose name or id match the specified name, or null if no nodes match.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.FormControlsCollection.NamedItem(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the node or list of nodes in the collection whose name or id match the specified name, or null if no nodes match.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Geolocation
member.summary:
The Geolocation interface represents an object able to programmatically obtain the position of the device. It gives Web content access to the location of the device. This allows a Web site or app offer customized results based on the user's location. An object with this interface is obtained using the NavigatorGeolocation.geolocation property implemented by the Navigator object.
Note: For security reasons, when a web page tries to access location information, the user is notified and asked to grant permission. Be aware that each browser has its own policies and methods for requesting this permission.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Geolocation.GetCurrentPosition(System.Delegate)
member.summary: Determines the device's current location and gives back a Position object with the data.
member.param: A callback function that takes a Position object as its sole input parameter.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Geolocation.WatchPosition(System.Delegate)
member.summary: The Geolocation.watchPosition() method is used to register a handler function that will be called automatically each time the position of the device changes. You can also, optionally, specify an error handling callback function.
member.param: A callback function that takes a Position object as an input parameter.
member.returns: This method returns a watch ID value than can be used to unregister the handler by passing it to the Geolocation.clearWatch() method.

member.param: The ID number returned by the Geolocation.watchPosition() method when installing the handler you wish to remove.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates
member.summary: The Coordinates interface represents the position and attitude of the device on Earth, as well as the accuracy with which these data are computed.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates.Latitude
member.summary: Returns a double representing the latitude of the position in decimal degrees.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates.Longitude
member.summary: Returns a double representing the longitude of the position in decimal degrees.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates.Altitude
member.summary: Returns a double representing the altitude of the position in meters, relative to sea level. This value can be null.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates.Accuracy
member.summary: Returns a double representing the accuracy of the latitude and longitude properties expressed in meters.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates.AltitudeAccuracy
member.summary: Returns a double representing the accuracy of the altitude expressed in meters. This value can be null.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates.Heading
member.summary: Returns a double representing the direction in which the device is traveling. This value, specified in degrees, indicates how far off from heading due north the device is. 0 degrees represents true true north, and the direction is determined clockwise (which means that east is 90 degrees and west is 270 degrees). If speed is 0, heading is NaN. If the device is not able to provide heading information, this value is null.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationCoordinates.Speed
member.summary: Returns a double representing the velocity of the device in meters per second. This value can be null.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPosition
member.summary: The Position interface represents the position of the concerned device at a given time. The position, represented by a Coordinates object, comprehends the 2D position of the device, on a spheroid representing the Earth, but also its altitude and its speed.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPosition.Coords
member.summary: Returns a GeolocationCoordinates object defining the current location.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPosition.Timestamp
member.summary: Returns a DOMTimeStamp representing the time at which the location was retrieved.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPositionError
member.summary: The PositionError interface represents the reason of an error occuring when using the geolocating device.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPositionError.Code
member.summary: Returns an unsigned short representing the error code.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPositionError.Message
member.summary: Returns a human-readable DOMString describing the details of the error.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationErrorCode.PermissionDenied
member.summary: The acquisition of the geolocation information failed because the page didn't have the permission to do it.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationErrorCode.PositionUnavailable
member.summary: The acquisition of the geolocation failed because one or several internal source of position returned an internal error.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationErrorCode.Timeout
member.summary: The time allowed to acquire the geolocation, defined by PositionOptions.timeout information was reached before the information was obtained.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPositionOptions
member.summary: The PositionOptions interface describes the options to use when calling the geolocation backend. The user agent itself doesn't create such an object itself: it is the calling script that create it and use it as a parameter of Geolocation.getCurrentPosition() and Geolocation.watchPosition().

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPositionOptions.EnableHighAccuracy
member.summary: Boolean property that indicates the application would like to receive the best possible results. If true and if the device is able to provide a more accurate position, it will do so. Note that this can result in slower response times or increased power consumption (with a GPS chip on a mobile device for example). On the other hand, if false (the default value), the device can take the liberty to save resources by responding more quickly and/or using less power.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPositionOptions.Timeout
member.summary: Positive long value representing the maximum length of time (in milliseconds) the device is allowed to take in order to return a position. The default value is Infinity, meaning that getCurrentPosition() won't return until the position is available.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.GeolocationPositionOptions.MaximumAge
member.summary: Positive long value indicating the maximum age in milliseconds of a possible cached position that is acceptable to return. If set to 0, it means that the device cannot use a cached position and must attempt to retrieve the real current position. If set to Infinity the device must return a cached position regardless of its age.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.History.Length
member.summary: Returns an Integer representing the number of elements in the session history, including the currently loaded page. For example, for a page loaded in a new tab this property returns 1.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.History.State
member.summary: Returns an any value representing the state at the top of the history stack. This is a way to look at the state without having to wait for a popstate event.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.History.Back
member.summary: Goes to the previous page in session history, the same action as when the user clicks the browser's Back button. Equivalent to history.go(-1). Note: Calling this method to go back beyond the first page in the session history has no effect and doesn't raise an exception.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.History.Forward
member.summary: Goes to the next page in session history, the same action as when the user clicks the browser's Forward button; this is equivalent to history.go(1). Note: Calling this method to go back beyond the last page in the session history has no effect and doesn't raise an exception.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.History.Go(System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads a page from the session history, identified by its relative location to the current page, for example -1 for the previous page or 1 for the next page. When integerDelta is out of bounds (e.g. -1 when there are no previously visited pages in the session history), the method doesn't do anything and doesn't raise an exception. Calling go() without parameters or with a non-integer argument has no effect (unlike Internet Explorer, which supports string URLs as the argument).

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.History.PushState(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Pushes the given data onto the session history stack with the specified title and, if provided, URL. The data is treated as opaque by the DOM; you may specify any JavaScript object that can be serialized.
member.param: The state object is a JavaScript object which is associated with the new history entry created by pushState(). Whenever the user navigates to the new state, a popstate event is fired, and the state property of the event contains a copy of the history entry's state object.

Firefox currently ignores this parameter, although it may use it in the future. Passing the empty string here should be safe against future changes to the method. Alternatively, you could pass a short title for the state to which you're moving.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.History.PushState(System.Object,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Pushes the given data onto the session history stack with the specified title and, if provided, URL. The data is treated as opaque by the DOM; you may specify any JavaScript object that can be serialized.
member.param: The state object is a JavaScript object which is associated with the new history entry created by pushState(). Whenever the user navigates to the new state, a popstate event is fired, and the state property of the event contains a copy of the history entry's state object.

Firefox currently ignores this parameter, although it may use it in the future. Passing the empty string here should be safe against future changes to the method. Alternatively, you could pass a short title for the state to which you're moving.

The new history entry's URL is given by this parameter. Note that the browser won't attempt to load this URL after a call to pushState(), but it might attempt to load the URL later, for instance after the user restarts the browser. The new URL does not need to be absolute; if it's relative, it's resolved relative to the current URL. The new URL must be of the same origin as the current URL; otherwise, pushState() will throw an exception. This parameter is optional; if it isn't specified, it's set to the document's current URL.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.History.ReplaceState(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Updates the most recent entry on the history stack to have the specified data, title, and, if provided, URL. The data is treated as opaque by the DOM; you may specify any JavaScript object that can be serialized.
member.param: The state object is a JavaScript object which is associated with the new history entry created by pushState(). Whenever the user navigates to the new state, a popstate event is fired, and the state property of the event contains a copy of the history entry's state object.

Firefox currently ignores this parameter, although it may use it in the future. Passing the empty string here should be safe against future changes to the method. Alternatively, you could pass a short title for the state to which you're moving.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.History.ReplaceState(System.Object,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Updates the most recent entry on the history stack to have the specified data, title, and, if provided, URL. The data is treated as opaque by the DOM; you may specify any JavaScript object that can be serialized.
member.param: The state object is a JavaScript object which is associated with the new history entry created by pushState(). Whenever the user navigates to the new state, a popstate event is fired, and the state property of the event contains a copy of the history entry's state object.

Firefox currently ignores this parameter, although it may use it in the future. Passing the empty string here should be safe against future changes to the method. Alternatively, you could pass a short title for the state to which you're moving.

The new history entry's URL is given by this parameter. Note that the browser won't attempt to load this URL after a call to pushState(), but it might attempt to load the URL later, for instance after the user restarts the browser. The new URL does not need to be absolute; if it's relative, it's resolved relative to the current URL. The new URL must be of the same origin as the current URL; otherwise, pushState() will throw an exception. This parameter is optional; if it isn't specified, it's set to the document's current URL.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.INodeFilter.AcceptNode(Bridge.Html5.Node)
member.summary: Returns an unsigned short that will be used to tell if a given Node must be accepted or not by the NodeIterator or TreeWalker iteration algorithm. This method is expected to be written by the user of a NodeFilter.
member.param: Node being the object to check against the filter.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilterResult.Accept
member.summary: Value returned by the NodeFilter.acceptNode() method when a node should be accepted.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilterResult.Reject
member.summary: Value to be returned by the NodeFilter.acceptNode() method when a node should be rejected. The children of rejected nodes are not visited by the NodeIterator or TreeWalker object; this value is treated as "skip this node and all its children".

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilterResult.Skip
member.summary: Value to be returned by NodeFilter.acceptNode() for nodes to be skipped by the NodeIterator or TreeWalker object. The children of skipped nodes are still considered. This is treated as "skip this node but not its children".

member.summary: String containing the whole URL.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Location.Protocol
member.summary: String containing the protocol scheme of the URL, including the final ':'.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Location.Hash
member.summary: String containing a '#' followed by the fragment identifier of the URL.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Location.Username
member.summary: String containing the username specified before the domain name.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Location.Password
member.summary: String containing the password specified before the domain name.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Location.Origin
member.summary: String containing the canonical form of the origin of the specific location.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Location.Assign(System.String)
member.summary: The Location.assign()method causes the window to load and display the document at the URL specified. If the assignment can't happen because of a security violation, a DOMException of the SECURITY_ERROR type is thrown. This happens if the origin of the script calling the method is different from the origin of the page originally described by the Location object, mostly when the script is hosted on a different domain. If the provided URL is not valid, a DOMException of the SYNTAX_ERROR type is thrown.
member.param: String containing the URL of the page to navigate to.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Location.Reload
member.summary: The Location.reload()method Reloads the resource from the current URL. Its optional unique parameter is a Boolean, which, when it is true, causes the page to always be reloaded from the server. If it is false or not specified, the browser may reload the page from its cache. If the assignment can't happen because of a security violation, a DOMException of the SECURITY_ERROR type is thrown. This happens if the origin of the script calling the method is different from the origin of the page originally described by the Location object, mostly when the script is hosted on a different domain.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Location.Reload(System.Boolean)
member.summary: The Location.reload()method Reloads the resource from the current URL. Its optional unique parameter is a Boolean, which, when it is true, causes the page to always be reloaded from the server. If it is false or not specified, the browser may reload the page from its cache. If the assignment can't happen because of a security violation, a DOMException of the SECURITY_ERROR type is thrown. This happens if the origin of the script calling the method is different from the origin of the page originally described by the Location object, mostly when the script is hosted on a different domain.
member.param: Boolean flag, which, when it is true, causes the page to always be reloaded from the server. If it is false or not specified, the browser may reload the page from its cache.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Location.Replace(System.String)
member.summary: The Location.replace()method replaces the current resource with the one at the provided URL. The difference from the assign() method is that after using replace() the current page will not be saved in session History, meaning the user won't be able to use the back button to navigate to it.
member.param: String containing the URL of the page to navigate to.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.MediaList
member.summary: MediaList representing the intended destination medium for style information.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList
member.summary: A MediaQueryList object maintains a list of media queries on a document, and handles sending notifications to listeners when the media queries on the document change. This makes it possible to observe a document to detect when its media queries change, instead of polling the values periodically, if you need to programmatically detect changes to the values of media queries on a document.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList.AddListener(System.Delegate)
member.summary: Adds a new listener to the media query list. If the specified listener is already in the list, this method has no effect.
member.param: The MediaQueryListListener to invoke when the media query's evaluated result changes.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList.AddListener(System.Action{Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList})
member.summary: Adds a new listener to the media query list. If the specified listener is already in the list, this method has no effect.
member.param: The MediaQueryListListener to invoke when the media query's evaluated result changes.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList.RemoveListener(System.Delegate)
member.summary: Removes a listener from the media query list. Does nothing if the specified listener isn't already in the list.
member.param: The MediaQueryListListener to stop calling on changes to the media query's evaluated result.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList.RemoveListener(System.Action{Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList})
member.summary: Removes a listener from the media query list. Does nothing if the specified listener isn't already in the list.
member.param: The MediaQueryListListener to stop calling on changes to the media query's evaluated result.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList.Matches
member.summary: true if the document currently matches the media query list; otherwise false. Read only.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.MediaQueryList.Media
member.summary: The serialized media query list.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter
member.summary: types of Node that must to be presented

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowAll
member.summary: Shows all nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowAttribute
member.summary: Shows attribute Attr nodes. This is meaningful only when creating a NodeIterator with an Attr node as its root; in this case, it means that the attribute node will appear in the first position of the iteration or traversal. Since attributes are never children of other nodes, they do not appear when traversing over the document tree.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowCdataSection
member.summary: Shows CDATASection nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowComment
member.summary: Shows Comment nodes.

member.summary: Shows Document nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowDocumentFragment
member.summary: Shows DocumentFragment nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowDocumentType
member.summary: Shows DocumentType nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowElement
member.summary: Shows Element nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowEntity
member.summary: Shows Entity nodes. This is meaningful only when creating a NodeIterator with an Entity node as its root; in this case, it means that the Entity node will appear in the first position of the traversal. Since entities are not part of the document tree, they do not appear when traversing over the document tree.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowEntityReference
member.summary: Shows EntityReference nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowNotation
member.summary: Shows Notation nodes. This is meaningful only when creating a NodeIterator with a Notation node as its root; in this case, it means that the Notation node will appear in the first position of the traversal. Since entities are not part of the document tree, they do not appear when traversing over the document tree.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowProcessingInstruction
member.summary: Shows ProcessingInstruction nodes.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeFilter.ShowText
member.summary: Shows Text nodes.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator
member.summary: The NodeIterator interface represents an iterator over the members of a list of the nodes in a subtree of the DOM. The nodes will be returned in document order. A NodeIterator can be created using the Document.createNodeIterator() method

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator.Root
member.summary: Returns a Node representing the root node as specified when the NodeIterator was created.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator.WhatToShow
member.summary: Returns an unsigned long being a bitmask made of constants describing the types of Node that must to be presented. Non-matching nodes are skipped, but their children may be included, if relevant.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator.ReferenceNode
member.summary: Returns the Node to which the iterator is anchored.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator.PointerBeforeReferenceNode
member.summary: Returns a Boolean flag that indicates whether the NodeFilter is anchored before, the flag being true, or after, the flag being false, the anchor node.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator.Detach
member.summary: This operation is a no-op. It doesn't do anything. Previously it was telling the engine that the NodeIterator was no more used, but this is now useless.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator.PreviousNode
member.summary: Returns the previous Node in the document, or null if there are none.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.NodeIterator.NextNode
member.summary: Returns the next Node in the document, or null if there are none.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Attr
member.summary: This type represents a DOM element's attribute as an object. In most DOM methods, you will probably directly retrieve the attribute as a string (e.g., Element.getAttribute(), but certain functions (e.g., Element.getAttributeNode()) or means of iterating give Attr types.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Attr.IsId
member.summary: Indicates whether the attribute is an "ID attribute". An "ID attribute" being an attribute which value is expected to be unique across a DOM Document. In HTML DOM, "id" is the only ID attribute, but XML documents could define others. Whether or not an attribute is unique is often determined by a DTD or other schema description.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Attr.Name
member.summary: The attribute's name.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Attr.Value
member.summary: The attribute's value.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.CDATASection
member.summary: A CDATA Section can be used within XML to include extended portions of unescaped text, such that the symbols < and & do not need escaping as they normally do within XML when used as text.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData
member.summary: The CharacterData abstract interface represents a Node object that contains characters. This is an abstract interface, meaning there aren't any object of type CharacterData: it is implemented by other interfaces, like Text, Comment, or ProcessingInstruction which aren't abstract.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.Data
member.summary: Is a DOMString representing the textual data contained in this object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.Length
member.summary: Returns an unsigned long representing the size of the string contained in CharacterData.data.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.PreviousElementSibling
member.summary: Returns the Element immediately prior to this ChildNode in its parent's children list, or null if there is no Element in the list prior to this ChildNode.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.NextElementSibling
member.summary: Returns the Element immediately following this ChildNode in its parent's children list, or null if there is no Element in the list following this ChildNode.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.AppendData(System.String)
member.summary: Appends the given DOMString to the CharacterData.data string; when this method returns, data contains the concatenated DOMString.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.DeleteData(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the specified amount of characters, starting at the specified offset, from the CharacterData.data string; when this method returns, data contains the shortened DOMString.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.InsertData(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Inserts the specified characters, at the specified offset, in the CharacterData.data string; when this method returns, data contains the modified DOMString.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.Remove
member.summary: Removes the object from its parent children list.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.ReplaceData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces the specified amount of characters, starting at the specified offset, with the specified DOMString; when this method returns, data contains the modified DOMString.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.CharacterData.SubstringData(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a DOMString containing the part of CharacterData.data of the specified length and starting at the specified offset.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Comment
member.summary: The Comment interface represents textual notations within markup; although it is generally not visually shown, such comments are available to be read in the source view. Comments are represented in HTML and XML as content between ''. In XML, the character sequence '--' cannot be used within a comment.

member.summary: Returns an item in the list by its index, or null if out-of-bounds.

member.summary: Returns an item in the list by its index, or null if out-of-bounds. Equivalent to nodeList[idx].

member.summary: The number of nodes in the NodeList.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.HTMLCollection`1
member.summary: The generic version of the HTMLCollection class. HTMLCollection is an class representing a generic collection (array) of elements (in document order) and offers methods and properties for selecting from the list.

member.name: P:Bridge.Html5.HTMLCollection`1.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the specific node at the given zero-based index into the list. Returns null if the index is out of range.

member.name: P:Bridge.Html5.HTMLCollection`1.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the specific node whose ID or, as a fallback, name matches the string specified by name. Matching by name is only done as a last resort, only in HTML, and only if the referenced element supports the name attribute. Returns null if no node exists by the given name.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.HTMLCollection`1.GetItem(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the specific node at the given zero-based index into the list. Returns null if the index is out of range.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.HTMLCollection`1.GetNamedItem(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the specific node whose ID or, as a fallback, name matches the string specified by name. Matching by name is only done as a last resort, only in HTML, and only if the referenced element supports the name attribute. Returns null if no node exists by the given name.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.HTMLCollection`1.Length
member.summary: The number of items in the collection.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.HTMLCollection
member.summary: The non-generic version of the HTMLCollection class. HTMLCollection is an class representing a generic collection (array) of elements (in document order) and offers methods and properties for selecting from the list.

member.summary: Just inside the element, after its last child.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.InsertPosition.AfterEnd
member.summary: After the element itself.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Node
member.summary: A Node is an interface from which a number of DOM types inherit, and allows these various types to be treated (or tested) similarly.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.BaseURI
member.summary: Returns a DOMString representing the base URL. The concept of base URL changes from one language to another; in HTML, it corresponds to the protocol, the domain name and the directory structure, that is all until the last '/'.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.ChildNodes
member.summary: Returns a live NodeList containing all the children of this node. NodeList being live means that if the children of the Node change, the NodeList object is automatically updated.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.FirstChild
member.summary: Returns a Node representing the first direct child node of the node, or null if the node has no child.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.LastChild
member.summary: Returns a Node representing the last direct child node of the node, or null if the node has no child.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.NextSibling
member.summary: Returns a Node representing the next node in the tree, or null if there isn't such node.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.NodeName
member.summary: Returns a DOMString containing the name of the Node. The structure of the name will differ with the name type. E.g. An HTMLElement will contain the name of the corresponding tag, like 'audio' for an HTMLAudioElement, a Text node will have the '#text' string, or a Document node will have the '#document' string.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.NodeType
member.summary: Returns an unsigned short representing the type of the node.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.NodeValue
member.summary: Is a DOMString representing the value of an object. For most Node type, this returns null and any set operation is ignored. For nodes of type TEXT_NODE (Text objects), COMMENT_NODE (Comment objects), and PROCESSING_INSTRUCTION_NODE (ProcessingInstruction objects), the value corresponds to the text data contained in the object.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.OwnerDocument
member.summary: Returns the Document that this node belongs to. If no document is associated with it, returns null.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.ParentNode
member.summary: Returns a Node that is the parent of this node. If there is no such node, like if this node is the top of the tree or if doesn't participate in a tree, this property returns null.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.ParentElement
member.summary: Returns an Element that is the parent of this node. If the node has no parent, or if that parent is not an Element, this property returns null.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.PreviousSibling
member.summary: Returns a Node representing the previous node in the tree, or null if there isn't such node.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Node.TextContent
member.summary: Is a DOMString representing the textual content of an element and all its descendants.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.AppendChild(Bridge.Html5.Node)
member.summary: Adds a node to the end of the list of children of a specified parent node. If the node already exists it is removed from current parent node, then added to new parent node.
member.param: child is the node to append underneath element. Also returned.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.CloneNode
member.summary: Returns a duplicate of the node on which this method was called.
member.returns: The new node that will be a clone of this node

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.CloneNode(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a duplicate of the node on which this method was called.
member.param: true if the children of the node should also be cloned, or false to clone only the specified node.
member.returns: The new node that will be a clone of this node

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.CompareDocumentPosition(Bridge.Html5.Node)
member.summary: Compares the position of the current node against another node in any other document.
member.param: is the node that's being compared against.
member.returns: The return value is computed as the relationship that otherNode has with node.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.Contains(Bridge.Html5.Node)
member.summary: Indicates whether a node is a descendant of a given node.
member.param: is the node that's being compared against.
member.returns: The return value is true if otherNode is a descendant of node, or node itself. Otherwise the return value is false.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.HasChildNodes
member.summary: returns a Boolean value indicating whether the current Node has child nodes or not.
member.returns: Boolean value indicating whether the current Node has child nodes or not

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.InsertBefore(Bridge.Html5.Node,Bridge.Html5.Node)
member.summary: Inserts the specified node before a reference element as a child of the current node.
member.param: The node to insert.
The node before which newElement is inserted.
member.returns: The node being inserted, that is newElement

member.param: string representing the namespace against which the element will be checked.
member.returns: holds the return value true or false.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.IsEqualNode(Bridge.Html5.Node)
member.summary: Tests whether two nodes are equal.
member.param: The node to compare equality with.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Node.Normalize

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.OptionsCollection
member.summary: HTMLOptionsCollection is an interface representing a collection of HTML option elements (in document order) and offers methods and properties for traversing the list as well as optionally altering its items.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.ProcessingInstruction
member.summary: A processing instruction provides an opportunity for application-specific instructions to be embedded within XML and which can be ignored by XML processors which do not support processing their instructions (outside of their having a place in the DOM).

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ProcessingInstruction.Target
member.summary: after the <? and before whitespace delimiting it from data

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ProcessingInstruction.Data
member.summary: first non-whitespace character after target and before ?>

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Text
member.summary: The Text interface represents the textual content of Element or Attr. If an element has no markup within its content, it has a single child implementing Text that contains the element's text. However, if the element contains markup, it is parsed into information items and Text nodes that form its children. New documents have a single Text node for each block of text. Over time, more Text nodes may be created as the document's content changes. The Node.normalize() method merges adjacent Text objects back into a single node for each block of text.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Text.WholeText
member.summary: Returns a DOMString containing the text of all Text nodes logically adjacent to this Node, concatenated in document order.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Text.SplitText(System.Int32)
member.summary: Breaks the node into two nodes at a specified offset.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.TextDirection
member.summary: The element attribute gets or sets the text writing directionality of the content of the current element.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.TextDirection.Auto
member.summary: direction of the element must be determined based on the contents of the element

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.TextDirection.Ltr
member.summary: left-to-right

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.TextDirection.Rtl
member.summary: right-to-left

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Performance.Now
member.summary: Returns a DOMHighResTimeStamp representing the amount of miliseconds elapsed since the start of the navigation, as give by PerformanceTiming.navigationStart to the call of the method.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Performance.Timing
member.summary: Is a PerformanceTiming object containing latency-related performance information.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Performance.Navigation
member.summary: Is a PerformanceNavigation object representing the type of navigation that occurs in the given browsing context, like the amount of redirections needed to fetch the resource.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming
member.summary: The PerformanceTiming interface represents timing-related performance information for the given page. An object of this type can be obtained by calling the Performance.timing read-only attribute.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.NavigationStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, right after the prompt for unload terminates on the previous document in the same browsing context. If there is no previous document, this value will be the same as PerformanceTiming.fetchStart.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.UnloadEventStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, the unload event has been thrown. If there is no previous document, or if the previous document, or one of the needed redirects, is not of the same origin, the value returned is 0.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.UnloadEventEnd
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, the unload event handler finishes. If there is no previous document, or if the previous document, or one of the needed redirects, is not of the same origin, the value returned is 0.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.RedirectStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, the first HTTP redirect starts. If there is no redirect, or if one of the redirect is not of the same origin, the value returned is 0.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.RedirectEnd
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, the last HTTP redirect is completed, that is when the last byte of the HTTP response has been received. If there is no redirect, or if one of the redirect is not of the same origin, the value returned is 0.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.FetchStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, the browser is ready to fetch the document using an HTTP request. This moment is before the check to any application cache.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.DomainLookupStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, where the domain lookup starts. If a persistent connection is used, or the information is stored in a cache or a local resource, the value will be the same as PerformanceTiming.fetchStart.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.DomainLookupEnd
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, where the domain lookup is finished. If a persistent connection is used, or the information is stored in a cache or a local resource, the value will be the same as PerformanceTiming.fetchStart.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.ConnectStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, where the request to open a connection is sent to the network. If the transport layer reports an error and the connection establishment is started again, the last connection establisment start time is given. If a persistent connection is used, the value will be the same as PerformanceTiming.fetchStart.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.ConnectEnd
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, where the connection is opened network. If the transport layer reports an error and the connection establishment is started again, the last connection establisment end time is given. If a persistent connection is used, the value will be the same as PerformanceTiming.fetchStart. A connection is considered as opened when all secure connection handshake, or SOCKS authentication, is terminated.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.SecureConnectionStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, where the secure connection handshake starts. If no such connection is requested, it returns 0.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.RequestStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the browser sent the request to obtain the actual document, from the server or from a cache. If the transport layer fails after the start of the request and the connection is reopened, this property will be set to the time corresponding to the new request.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.ResponseStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the browser received the first byte of the response, from the server from a cache, of from a local resource.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.ResponseEnd
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the browser received the last byte of the response, or when the connection is closed if this happened first, from the server from a cache, of from a local resource.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.DomLoading
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the parser started its work, that is when its Document.readyState changes to 'loading' and the corresponding readystatechange event is thrown.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.DomInteractive
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the parser finished its work on the main document, that is when its Document.readyState changes to 'interactive' and the corresponding readystatechange event is thrown.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.DomContentLoadedEventStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, right before the parser sent the DOMContentLoaded event, that is right after all the scripts that need to be executed right after parsing has been executed.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.DomContentLoadedEventEnd
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, right after all the scripts that need to be executed as soon as possible, in order or not, has been executed.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.DomComplete
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the parser finished its work on the main document, that is when its Document.readyState changes to 'complete' and the corresponding readystatechange event is thrown.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.LoadEventStart
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the load event was sent for the current document. If this event has not yet been sent, it returns 0.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceTiming.LoadEventEnd
member.summary: Is an int representing the moment, in miliseconds since the UNIX epoch, when the load event handler terminated, that is when the load event is completed. If this event has not yet been sent, or is not yet completed, it returns 0.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigation
member.summary: The PerformanceNavigation interface represents information about how the navigation to the current document was done. An object of this type can be obtained by calling the Performance.navigation read-only attribute.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigation.Type
member.summary: Is an short containing a constant describing how the navigation to this page was done.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigation.RedirectCount
member.summary: Is an short representing the number of REDIRECTs done before reaching the page.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigationType
member.summary: A constant describing how the navigation to this page was done.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigationType.Navigate
member.summary: The page was accessed by following a link, a bookmark, a form submission, a script, or typing the URL in the address bar.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigationType.Reload
member.summary: The page was accessed by clicking the Reload button or via the Location.reload() method.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigationType.BackForward
member.summary: The page was accessed by navigating into the history.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.PerformanceNavigationType.Reserved
member.summary: Any other way.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.ReadyState
member.summary: loading status of the document

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ReadyState.Loading
member.summary: "loading" while the document is loading

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ReadyState.Interactive
member.summary: "interactive" once the document is finished parsing but still loading sub-resources

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.ReadyState.Complete
member.summary: "complete" once the document has loaded

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Screen
member.summary: The screen object is a special object for inspecting properties of the screen on which the current window is being rendered.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.AvailTop
member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the first pixel that is not allocated to permanent or semipermanent user interface features.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.AvailLeft
member.summary: Returns the first available pixel available from the left side of the screen.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.AvailHeight
member.summary: Specifies the height of the screen, in pixels, minus permanent or semipermanent user interface features displayed by the operating system, such as the Taskbar on Windows.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.AvailWidth
member.summary: Returns the amount of horizontal space in pixels available to the window.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.ColotDepth
member.summary: Returns the color depth of the screen.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.Height
member.summary: Returns the height of the screen in pixels.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.Left
member.summary: Returns the distance in pixels from the left side of the main screen to the left side of the current screen.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.PixelDepth
member.summary: Gets the bit depth of the screen.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.Top
member.summary: Returns the distance in pixels from the top side of the current screen.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Screen.Width
member.summary: Returns the width of the screen.

member.name: T:Bridge.Html5.Range
member.summary: The Range interface represents a fragment of a document that can contain nodes and parts of text nodes in a given document. A range can be created using the createRange method of the Document object. Range objects can also be retrieved by using the getRangeAt method of the Selection object. There also is the Range() constructor available.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Range.Collapsed
member.summary: Returns a Boolean indicating whether the range's start and end points are at the same position.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Range.CommonAncestorContainer

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Range.EndContainer
member.summary: Returns the Node within which the Range ends.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Range.EndOffset
member.summary: Returns a number representing where in the endContainer the Range ends.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Range.StartContainer
member.summary: Returns the Node within which the Range starts.

member.name: F:Bridge.Html5.Range.StartOffset
member.summary: Returns a number representing where in the startContainer the Range starts.

An integer greater than or equal to zero representing the offset for the start of the Range from the start of startNode.

An integer greater than or equal to zero representing the offset for the end of the Range from the start of endNode.

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Range.SetEndAfter(Bridge.Html5.Node)

member.name: M:Bridge.Html5.Range.SelectNode(Bridge.Html5.Node)
